Remarkable Progress Highlights Closing Months of 1955
Sacred Heart-TV Programs on 40 Stations
Dear Friends:
I think you will agree with us as you
.read over this Winter issue of the
“NEWS and VIEWS”—that our watch¬
word has been progress and expansion.
However, progress and expansion are
not always for the best. For instance,
the Reds are making progress with athe¬
istic communism and are expanding their
armed might. But the consoling part
about our steady development is that
it carries forward into ever wider fields
and more numerous channels the beauti¬
ful standard of the Sacred Heart of
Jesus. We can now say we have planted
that standard firmly in the world of tele¬
vision. We are there not only to stay,
but to spread ever wider and wider the
Love burning in the Sacred Heart for all
men—a Love that will never find its
all-consuming flames satisfied until all
men are happy in this world and saved
for all eternity.
Father Walter Flaherty, Director of
Radio and TV for the Boston Archdio¬
cese, brought out in his address at our
annual dinner last September that if
men can spend hundreds of thousands
of dollars on meaningless and puerile
programs, surely we can contribute pain¬
lessly and sacrificially to the support of
a program dedicated to bringing to a
despairing world the solid food that
nourishes not the body but the soul unto
life—unto eternal life.
Your generosity to date has justified
us in going ahead with the work despite
mounting costs. We now must raise
$900.00 every week to keep the radio and
TV broadcasts on the air in this north-

There are fine prospects that this 15-minute TV program will soon be in New
York City, Boston, New Haven, Springfield and Syracuse with weekly TV.
From our central offices in St. Louis come reports of similar expansion throughout
the country.
Enthusiastic
Mrs. Dumaine
Meeting Held In W. Springfield, Mass.
On October 17 some 200 promoters and friends of the program
crowded into the Knights of Columbus Hall in W. Springfield, Mass.,
for an address by Father Hale. This remarkable assembly was
due in large part to Mrs. Theodore Dumaine and her corps of
indefatigable fellow-workers.
Mayor Trybulski of Chicopee welcomed the assemblage. Mrs.
Daniel B. Brunton represented her husband, Mayor Brunton of
Springfield. Mr. Emmons Purcell represented the Knights and
served as Master of Ceremonies for the evening. The hall was
donated by the Knights.
Also honoring us by their presence were; Selectmen Raymond
J. Rosa and Walter J. Cogan of W. Springfield; Mr. Howard Keefe
of WWLP, and Mrs. Keefe; and Robert Boulay, Civil Defense Dis¬
trict Director.
Films of the “Mission of a Jesuit” and of “Sacred Heart TV
Program” were shown by James Shea of Chicopee Falls. Organi¬
zations represented at the meeting included: Blessed Virgin Sodal¬
ity of St. Thomas Church, West Springfield; Apostleship of Prayer,
St. George’s Church, Chicopee Falls; St. Thomas Women’s Club of
West Springfield; Holy Name Society, Holy Name Church, Chicopee;
Daughters of Isabella, Springfield; College of Our Lady of the Elms,
Chicopee; Sacred Heart High School, Springfield; Holy Family
Women’s Club, Holy Family Church, Springfield; St. Ann’s Society,
